text: imagine that you are a pig farmer you
live on a small farm in the Philippines
your animals are your family's sole

your pigs can catch the flu the swine
flu living in tight quarters one pig
coughing and sneezing May soon lead to

an outbreak of swine flu has taken over
your farm if it's a bad enough virus the

noses and mouths but then they would
have to drive back into the city to test
those samples in their Central lab two
weeks later you'd hear back the results
2 weeks may be just enough time for

samples themselves they can jump right
into the pen and swap their pix nosis
and mouths with a little filter paper
and place that little filter paper in a
tiny tube mix it with some chemicals
that will extract genetic material from
their pigs noses and mouths and without
leaving their Farms take a drop of that
genetic material and put it into a
little analyzer smaller than a shoe box
and program it to detect DNA or RNA from
the swine flu virus and within one hour
get back the results visualize the
results this reality is possible because
today we're living in the era of
personal DNA technology every one of us
can actually test DNA ourselves DNA is
the fundamental molecule that carries

Living World humans have DNA pigs have
DNA even bacteria and some viruses have
DNA too the genetic instructions encoded
in DNA inform how our bodies develop
grow function and in many cases that
same information can trigger disease
your genetic information is strung into
a long and twisted molecule the DNA
double helix that has over 3 billion
letters beginning to end but the lines
that carry meaningful information are
usually very short a few dozen to
several thousand letters long so when
we're looking to answer a question based
on DNA we actually don't need to read
all those three billion letters
typically that would be like getting
hungry at night and having to flip
through the whole phone book from cover

find the nearest pizza
joint luckily three decades ago humans
started to invent tools that can find
any specific line of genetic information
these DNA machines are wonderful they
can find any line in DNA but once they

surrounded by so much other DNA what
that what these machines then do is copy
the target Gene and one copy piles on
top of another millions and millions and
millions of copies until that Gene

until we can visualize it interpret it
read it understand it until we can
answer does my pig have the

child my
son this ability to make copies of DNA
as simple as it sounds has transformed

Innovative medicines to modify foods to

bacteria even judges use the output of

whether someone is innocent or guilty

Everyday people like the pig farmer like

cedra we decided to make personal DNA

what could the world look like if

I've learned from Paul that the stakes

when astronauts live aboard the
